head.title: For Biotech Food, We Need Full Labeling

hedline.hl1: For Biotech Food, We Need Full Labeling

abstract.p: Letter by Richard Caplan of Public Interest Research Group calls for full labeling for all genetically engineered ingredients in food

block.p: The Clinton administration's new proposal regarding agricultural biotechnology (news article, May 4) is a welcome acknowledgment that current oversight needs improvement, but the proposal is inadequate.

The Food and Drug Administration has proposed making consultations mandatory for institutions that are seeking to commercialize genetically engineered crops, but has failed to announce a system for comprehensive pre-market safety testing.

The Clinton administration's new proposal regarding agricultural biotechnology (news article, May 4) is a welcome acknowledgment that current oversight needs improvement, but the proposal is inadequate.

The Food and Drug Administration has proposed making consultations mandatory for institutions that are seeking to commercialize genetically engineered crops, but has failed to announce a system for comprehensive pre-market safety testing.

Allowing companies to voluntarily label their products as ''free of genetic engineering'' is a bad idea. What we need is labeling for all genetically engineered ingredients, and the proposal undercuts that.
We and others recently filed a petition calling on the administration for mandatory pre-market testing of all genetically engineered foods, mandatory labeling and full environmental review.
This is the only system that would effectively serve the public's best interests.
U.S. Public Interest Research Group Washington, May 4, 2000
